Report Status :
Signed
DISCHARGE SUMMARY
NAME :
WURHEAGLEA , OSASANT
UNIT NUMBER :
034-98-19
ADMISSION DATE :
02/02/2003
DISCHARGE DATE :
02/09/2003
CHIEF COMPLAINT :
Left hip pain .
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS :
The patient was seen by Dr. Overall in the office on Aug 22 , 2003 , for follow-up .
She was scheduled to have a total hi p replacement because of progressively worsening pain in the left hip .
Her pain was 8/10 .
She limped .
She did not use a cane .
She did require a bannister going up and down stairs .
She had trouble doing shoes and socks .
She could walk limited distances .
Since seen by Dr. Overall in August , she had had a brain aneurysm .
She had a mastectomy and had recently developed Parkinson 's.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY :
1. Breast cancer in the right breast , diagnosed in 1995 with negative nodes , treated with excision , recurrence in June , 2001 , further reconstructive surgery .
At the same time , she underwent reduction of t he left breast .
2. History of bipolar disorder , for which she sees Dr. Lettefriscbreun .
She indicates this is stable at this time .
3. History of chronic anxiety .
4. Sleep apnea treated with UPP surgery in 1997 .
She does not use CPAP .
5. History of diverticulitis .
6. Intermittent migraines .
7. History of prior cervical dysplasia , treated with LEEP procedure .
8. Osteoporosis .
9. Obsessive-compulsive disorder .
10. Panic disorder .
11. Aneurysm of the right internal auditory canal , treated with coil insertion .
12. Prior renal surgery .
MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION :
1. Eskalith , 300 mg. twice at bedtime .
2. Femara , 2.5 mg. at bedtime .
3. Primidone , 50 mg. PO q.h.s.
4. Diazepam , 1 mg. PO q.h.s.
5. Paxil , 37.5 mg. q.a.m.
6. Synthroid , 100 mcg. q.a.m.
7. Ditropan XL , 10 mg.
8. Imodium , 2 mg. q.a.m.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION :
Examination reveals that the patient is walking with a mild limp .
The left hip is a bit stiff with flexion to 90 degrees .
She has 10 degrees of internal rotation and external rotation .
Pulses are fine .
IMAGING :
X-rays were reviewed .
They showed advanced arthritis of the left hip .
RECOMMENDATIONS :
Dr. Etteme Overall recommended that the patient have a total hip replacement on the left side on February 2 , 2003 .
HOSPITAL COURSE :
Please refer to the operative note by Dr. Etteme Overall for details of the procedure .
Postoperatively , the patient was transferred to the floor in stable condition for observation , pain control and mobilization .
Initially postoperatively , she was doing quite well , though she did require four liters of oxygen postoperatively to maintain her oxygen saturations .
It was hoped that she would wean off the oxygen over the course of the next few hours .
However , she did require four liters of oxygen all the way through the night to maintain oxygen saturations of 93% .
Without oxygen , she dropped down to the low 80s .
Given the unusual nature of this oxygen requirement , the patient underwent work-up with a chest X-ray , which essentially was normal .
An ABG revealed a normal PCO2 of 32 , but a decrease in PO2- at 62 .
Therefore , given her history of breast cancer , the patient was taken for a spiral CT scan and the Medicine Service was consulted at that time .
They agreed with our plan .
On spiral CT scan , a small pulmonary embolus was seen in the right upper lobe and the left low er lobe .
She was started on heparin at that time to maintain a PTT of 60 t o 80 , and was given doses of Coumadin , in addition to the Coumadin she had been given for DVT prophylaxis .
With the recommendation of the medicine te am , we decided to maintain an INR of 2 to 3 with an overlap of heparin when the patient was therapeutic for two to three days .
She continued to do quite well even though we did keep her on bed rest for three days while she was heparinized .
Her oxygen saturations continued to improve to the point that she was on room air on postoperative day four with oxygen saturation of 95% .
She was given perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis for 48 hours after surgery .
She was mobilized on postoperative day four , getting out of bed , able to do quite well on her new hip with a minimal amount of pain .
She was given posterior hip dislocation precautions at that time , which she understood quite well .
She continued to be followed by the medical team and was watched very closely by the orthopedic team until we felt comfortable that she was breathing quite well and was mobilizing well with physical therapy .
Therefore , it was decided at that time that the patient was ready for discharge to rehabilitation on Coumadin , which would be monitored for six months to maintain an INR of 2.0 to 3.0 .
MEDICATIONS ON DISCHARGE :
The patient will continue all of her pre-admission medications , though no nonsteroidal analgesics , e.g. , aspirin or ibuprofen , will be given while she is on Coumadin therapy .
1. Colace , 100 mg. PO t.i.d.
2. Percocet , one to two tablets PO q.3 to 4 hours p.r.n. pain .
3. Coumadin with a target INR of 2.0 to 3.0 .
Please prescribe 2 mg. tablets .
The patient will be on Coumadin for six months given her history of pulmonary embolus .
DISCHARGE PLAN :
Coumadin for six months postoperatively with a target INR of 2.0 to 3.0 .
Check INR three times a week until stable .
Please call the results to Dr. Viennee Ester , the patient 's primary-care physician , who has agreed to follow her INR levels for the remainder of the six months .
Dr. Viennee Ester is located in Tlandcousti Lo Vuclark , where the patient is from originally .
The patient will call Dr. Overall 's office to arrange a follow-up appointment six weeks from the day of surgery .
Staples can be removed 10 to 14 days postoperatively .
Please hold removal if the wound is draining .
The patient may shower once the incision is dry , and may bathe and / or swim after the staples have been removed and there is no wound drainage .
Partial weight-bearing with crutches or a walker with posterior hip dislocation precautions for three months following surgery .
These precautions have been explained and demonstrated to the patient .
The patient has been instructed to call Dr. Overall 's office or the orthopedist on call with any questions or concerns about increasing pain , swelling , redness , wound drainage , fevers or chills at 094-897-3231 .

2. History of bipolar disorder , for which she sees Dr. Lettefriscbreun .
She indicates this is stable at this time .
3. History of chronic anxiety .
4. Sleep apnea treated with UPP surgery in 1997 .
She does not use CPAP .
5. History of diverticulitis .
6. Intermittent migraines .
7. History of prior cervical dysplasia , treated with LEEP procedure .
8. Osteoporosis .
9. Obsessive-compulsive disorder .
10. Panic disorder .
11. Aneurysm of the right internal auditory canal , treated with coil insertion .
12. Prior renal surgery .
MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION :
1. Eskalith , 300 mg. twice at bedtime .
2. Femara , 2.5 mg. at bedtime .
3. Primidone , 50 mg. PO q.h.s.
4. Diazepam , 1 mg. PO q.h.s.
5. Paxil , 37.5 mg. q.a.m.
6. Synthroid , 100 mcg. q.a.m.
7. Ditropan XL , 10 mg.
8. Imodium , 2 mg. q.a.m.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION :
Examination reveals that the patient is walking with a mild limp .
The left hip is a bit stiff with flexion to 90 degrees .
She has 10 degrees of internal rotation and external rotation .
Pulses are fine .
IMAGING :
X-rays were reviewed .
They showed advanced arthritis of the left hip .
RECOMMENDATIONS :
Dr. Etteme Overall recommended that the patient have a total hip replacement on the left side on February 2 , 2003 .
HOSPITAL COURSE :
Please refer to the operative note by Dr. Etteme Overall for details of the procedure .
Postoperatively , the patient was transferred to the floor in stable condition for observation , pain control and mobilization .
Initially postoperatively , she was doing quite well , though she did require four liters of oxygen postoperatively to maintain her oxygen saturations .
It was hoped that she would wean off the oxygen over the course of the next few hours .
However , she did require four liters of oxygen all the way through the night to maintain oxygen saturations of 93% .
Without oxygen , she dropped down to the low 80s .
Given the unusual nature of this oxygen requirement , the patient underwent work-up with a chest X-ray , which essentially was normal .
An ABG revealed a normal PCO2 of 32 , but a decrease in PO2- at 62 .
Therefore , given her history of breast cancer , the patient was taken for a spiral CT scan and the Medicine Service was consulted at that time .
They agreed with our plan .
On spiral CT scan , a small pulmonary embolus was seen in the right upper lobe and the left low er lobe .
She was started on heparin at that time to maintain a PTT of 60 t o 80 , and was given doses of Coumadin , in addition to the Coumadin she had been given for DVT prophylaxis .
With the recommendation of the medicine te am , we decided to maintain an INR of 2 to 3 with an overlap of heparin when the patient was therapeutic for two to three days .
She continued to do quite well even though we did keep her on bed rest for three days while she was heparinized .
Her oxygen saturations continued to improve to the point that she was on room air on postoperative day four with oxygen saturation of 95% .
She was given perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis for 48 hours after surgery .
She was mobilized on postoperative day four , getting out of bed , able to do quite well on her new hip with a minimal amount of pain .
She was given posterior hip dislocation precautions at that time , which she understood quite well .
She continued to be followed by the medical team and was watched very closely by the orthopedic team until we felt comfortable that she was breathing quite well and was mobilizing well with physical therapy .
Therefore , it was decided at that time that the patient was ready for discharge to rehabilitation on Coumadin , which would be monitored for six months to maintain an INR of 2.0 to 3.0 .
MEDICATIONS ON DISCHARGE :
The patient will continue all of her pre-admission medications , though no nonsteroidal analgesics , e.g. , aspirin or ibuprofen , will be given while she is on Coumadin therapy .
1. Colace , 100 mg. PO t.i.d.
2. Percocet , one to two tablets PO q.3 to 4 hours p.r.n. pain .
3. Coumadin with a target INR of 2.0 to 3.0 .
Please prescribe 2 mg. tablets .
The patient will be on Coumadin for six months given her history of pulmonary embolus .
DISCHARGE PLAN :
Coumadin for six months postoperatively with a target INR of 2.0 to 3.0 .
Check INR three times a week until stable .
Please call the results to Dr. Viennee Ester , the patient 's primary-care physician , who has agreed to follow her INR levels for the remainder of the six months .
Dr. Viennee Ester is located in Tlandcousti Lo Vuclark , where the patient is from originally .
The patient will call Dr. Overall 's office to arrange a follow-up appointment six weeks from the day of surgery .
Staples can be removed 10 to 14 days postoperatively .
Please hold removal if the wound is draining .
The patient may shower once the incision is dry , and may bathe and / or swim after the staples have been removed and there is no wound drainage .
Partial weight-bearing with crutches or a walker with posterior hip dislocation precautions for three months following surgery .
These precautions have been explained and demonstrated to the patient .
The patient has been instructed to call Dr. Overall 's office or the orthopedist on call with any questions or concerns about increasing pain , swelling , redness , wound drainage , fevers or chills at 094-897-3231 .

X-rays were reviewed .
They showed advanced arthritis of the left hip .

Without oxygen , she dropped down to the low 80s .

WURHEAGLEA , OSASANT
UNIT NUMBER :
034-98-19

02/02/2003
DISCHARGE DATE :
02/09/2003
CHIEF COMPLAINT :
Left hip pain .
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS :
The patient was seen by Dr. Overall in the office on Aug 22 , 2003 , for follow-up .
She was scheduled to have a total hi p replacement because of progressively worsening pain in the left hip .
Her pain was 8/10 .
She limped .
She did not use a cane .
She did require a bannister going up and down stairs .
She had trouble doing shoes and socks .
She could walk limited distances .
Since seen by Dr. Overall in August , she had had a brain aneurysm .
She had a mastectomy and had recently developed Parkinson 's.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY :
1. Breast cancer in the right breast , diagnosed in 1995 with negative nodes , treated with excision , recurrence in June , 2001 , further reconstructive surgery .
At the same time , she underwent reduction of t he left breast .
2. History of bipolar disorder , for which she sees Dr. Lettefriscbreun .
She indicates this is stable at this time .
3. History of chronic anxiety .
4. Sleep apnea treated with UPP surgery in 1997 .
She does not use CPAP .
5. History of diverticulitis .
6. Intermittent migraines .
7. History of prior cervical dysplasia , treated with LEEP procedure .
8. Osteoporosis .
9. Obsessive-compulsive disorder .
10. Panic disorder .
11. Aneurysm of the right internal auditory canal , treated with coil insertion .
12. Prior renal surgery .
MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION :
1. Eskalith , 300 mg. twice at bedtime .
2. Femara , 2.5 mg. at bedtime .
3. Primidone , 50 mg. PO q.h.s.
4. Diazepam , 1 mg. PO q.h.s.
5. Paxil , 37.5 mg. q.a.m.
6. Synthroid , 100 mcg. q.a.m.
7. Ditropan XL , 10 mg.
8. Imodium , 2 mg. q.a.m.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION :
Examination reveals that the patient is walking with a mild limp .
The left hip is a bit stiff with flexion to 90 degrees .
She has 10 degrees of internal rotation and external rotation .
Pulses are fine .
IMAGING :
X-rays were reviewed .
They showed advanced arthritis of the left hip .
RECOMMENDATIONS :
Dr. Etteme Overall recommended that the patient have a total hip replacement on the left side on February 2 , 2003 .
HOSPITAL COURSE :
Please refer to the operative note by Dr. Etteme Overall for details of the procedure .
Postoperatively , the patient was transferred to the floor in stable condition for observation , pain control and mobilization .
Initially postoperatively , she was doing quite well , though she did require four liters of oxygen postoperatively to maintain her oxygen saturations .
It was hoped that she would wean off the oxygen over the course of the next few hours .
However , she did require four liters of oxygen all the way through the night to maintain oxygen saturations of 93% .
Without oxygen , she dropped down to the low 80s .
Given the unusual nature of this oxygen requirement , the patient underwent work-up with a chest X-ray , which essentially was normal .
An ABG revealed a normal PCO2 of 32 , but a decrease in PO2- at 62 .
Therefore , given her history of breast cancer , the patient was taken for a spiral CT scan and the Medicine Service was consulted at that time .
They agreed with our plan .
On spiral CT scan , a small pulmonary embolus was seen in the right upper lobe and the left low er lobe .
She was started on heparin at that time to maintain a PTT of 60 t o 80 , and was given doses of Coumadin , in addition to the Coumadin she had been given for DVT prophylaxis .
With the recommendation of the medicine te am , we decided to maintain an INR of 2 to 3 with an overlap of heparin when the patient was therapeutic for two to three days .
She continued to do quite well even though we did keep her on bed rest for three days while she was heparinized .
Her oxygen saturations continued to improve to the point that she was on room air on postoperative day four with oxygen saturation of 95% .
She was given perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis for 48 hours after surgery .
She was mobilized on postoperative day four , getting out of bed , able to do quite well on her new hip with a minimal amount of pain .
She was given posterior hip dislocation precautions at that time , which she understood quite well .
She continued to be followed by the medical team and was watched very closely by the orthopedic team until we felt comfortable that she was breathing quite well and was mobilizing well with physical therapy .
Therefore , it was decided at that time that the patient was ready for discharge to rehabilitation on Coumadin , which would be monitored for six months to maintain an INR of 2.0 to 3.0 .
MEDICATIONS ON DISCHARGE :
The patient will continue all of her pre-admission medications , though no nonsteroidal analgesics , e.g. , aspirin or ibuprofen , will be given while she is on Coumadin therapy .

Please prescribe 2 mg. tablets .

Coumadin for six months postoperatively with a target INR of 2.0 to 3.0 .
Check INR three times a week until stable .
Please call the results to Dr. Viennee Ester , the patient 's primary-care physician , who has agreed to follow her INR levels for the remainder of the six months .
Dr. Viennee Ester is located in Tlandcousti Lo Vuclark , where the patient is from originally .
The patient will call Dr. Overall 's office to arrange a follow-up appointment six weeks from the day of surgery .
Staples can be removed 10 to 14 days postoperatively .
Please hold removal if the wound is draining .
The patient may shower once the incision is dry , and may bathe and / or swim after the staples have been removed and there is no wound drainage .
Partial weight-bearing with crutches or a walker with posterior hip dislocation precautions for three months following surgery .

DISCHARGE SUMMARY
NAME :
WURHEAGLEA , OSASANT
UNIT NUMBER :
034-98-19
ADMISSION DATE :
02/02/2003
DISCHARGE DATE :
02/09/2003
CHIEF COMPLAINT :
Left hip pain .
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS :
The patient was seen by Dr. Overall in the office on Aug 22 , 2003 , for follow-up .
She was scheduled to have a total hi p replacement because of progressively worsening pain in the left hip .
Her pain was 8/10 .
She limped .
She did not use a cane .
She did require a bannister going up and down stairs .
She had trouble doing shoes and socks .
She could walk limited distances .
Since seen by Dr. Overall in August , she had had a brain aneurysm .
She had a mastectomy and had recently developed Parkinson 's.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY :
1. Breast cancer in the right breast , diagnosed in 1995 with negative nodes , treated with excision , recurrence in June , 2001 , further reconstructive surgery .
At the same time , she underwent reduction of t he left breast .
2. History of bipolar disorder , for which she sees Dr. Lettefriscbreun .
She indicates this is stable at this time .
3. History of chronic anxiety .
4. Sleep apnea treated with UPP surgery in 1997 .
She does not use CPAP .
5. History of diverticulitis .
6. Intermittent migraines .
7. History of prior cervical dysplasia , treated with LEEP procedure .
8. Osteoporosis .
9. Obsessive-compulsive disorder .
10. Panic disorder .
11. Aneurysm of the right internal auditory canal , treated with coil insertion .
12. Prior renal surgery .
MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION :
1. Eskalith , 300 mg. twice at bedtime .
2. Femara , 2.5 mg. at bedtime .
3. Primidone , 50 mg. PO q.h.s.
4. Diazepam , 1 mg. PO q.h.s.
5. Paxil , 37.5 mg. q.a.m.
6. Synthroid , 100 mcg. q.a.m.
7. Ditropan XL , 10 mg.
8. Imodium , 2 mg. q.a.m.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION :
Examination reveals that the patient is walking with a mild limp .
The left hip is a bit stiff with flexion to 90 degrees .
She has 10 degrees of internal rotation and external rotation .
Pulses are fine .
IMAGING :
X-rays were reviewed .
They showed advanced arthritis of the left hip .
RECOMMENDATIONS :
Dr. Etteme Overall recommended that the patient have a total hip replacement on the left side on February 2 , 2003 .
HOSPITAL COURSE :
Please refer to the operative note by Dr. Etteme Overall for details of the procedure .
Postoperatively , the patient was transferred to the floor in stable condition for observation , pain control and mobilization .
Initially postoperatively , she was doing quite well , though she did require four liters of oxygen postoperatively to maintain her oxygen saturations .
It was hoped that she would wean off the oxygen over the course of the next few hours .
However , she did require four liters of oxygen all the way through the night to maintain oxygen saturations of 93% .
Without oxygen , she dropped down to the low 80s .
Given the unusual nature of this oxygen requirement , the patient underwent work-up with a chest X-ray , which essentially was normal .
An ABG revealed a normal PCO2 of 32 , but a decrease in PO2- at 62 .
Therefore , given her history of breast cancer , the patient was taken for a spiral CT scan and the Medicine Service was consulted at that time .
They agreed with our plan .
On spiral CT scan , a small pulmonary embolus was seen in the right upper lobe and the left low er lobe .
She was started on heparin at that time to maintain a PTT of 60 t o 80 , and was given doses of Coumadin , in addition to the Coumadin she had been given for DVT prophylaxis .
With the recommendation of the medicine te am , we decided to maintain an INR of 2 to 3 with an overlap of heparin when the patient was therapeutic for two to three days .
She continued to do quite well even though we did keep her on bed rest for three days while she was heparinized .
Her oxygen saturations continued to improve to the point that she was on room air on postoperative day four with oxygen saturation of 95% .
She was given perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis for 48 hours after surgery .
She was mobilized on postoperative day four , getting out of bed , able to do quite well on her new hip with a minimal amount of pain .
She was given posterior hip dislocation precautions at that time , which she understood quite well .
She continued to be followed by the medical team and was watched very closely by the orthopedic team until we felt comfortable that she was breathing quite well and was mobilizing well with physical therapy .
Therefore , it was decided at that time that the patient was ready for discharge to rehabilitation on Coumadin , which would be monitored for six months to maintain an INR of 2.0 to 3.0 .
MEDICATIONS ON DISCHARGE :
The patient will continue all of her pre-admission medications , though no nonsteroidal analgesics , e.g. , aspirin or ibuprofen , will be given while she is on Coumadin therapy .
1. Colace , 100 mg. PO t.i.d.
2. Percocet , one to two tablets PO q.3 to 4 hours p.r.n. pain .
3. Coumadin with a target INR of 2.0 to 3.0 .
Please prescribe 2 mg. tablets .
The patient will be on Coumadin for six months given her history of pulmonary embolus .
DISCHARGE PLAN :
Coumadin for six months postoperatively with a target INR of 2.0 to 3.0 .
Check INR three times a week until stable .
Please call the results to Dr. Viennee Ester , the patient 's primary-care physician , who has agreed to follow her INR levels for the remainder of the six months .
Dr. Viennee Ester is located in Tlandcousti Lo Vuclark , where the patient is from originally .
The patient will call Dr. Overall 's office to arrange a follow-up appointment six weeks from the day of surgery .
Staples can be removed 10 to 14 days postoperatively .
Please hold removal if the wound is draining .
The patient may shower once the incision is dry , and may bathe and / or swim after the staples have been removed and there is no wound drainage .
Partial weight-bearing with crutches or a walker with posterior hip dislocation precautions for three months following surgery .
These precautions have been explained and demonstrated to the patient .
The patient has been instructed to call Dr. Overall 's office or the orthopedist on call with any questions or concerns about increasing pain , swelling , redness , wound drainage , fevers or chills at 094-897-3231 .

OSA ( obstructive sleep apnea ) - Primary G47.33

Progress Notes

Progress Notes signed by Pauline Bos , MD at 1/10/2018 1:08 PM Author : Pauline Bos , Author Physician Filed :

MD Type : Note Signed Cosign : Cosign Not Required Encounter 1/10/2018

Status : Date : Editor : CC : OSA

History of present illness

Very pleasant 52-year-old man with a long-standing history of chronic snoring along with prior septoplasty in high school .

He recalls symptoms of chronic sleepiness dating back many years as well which he states limited his ability to be the best Astronomer ever dispiste his success with Led Zeppelin as the lead guitarist . Within the context of these symptoms his wife ( Rosalind Columbia ) noticed witnessed apneas which were brought to his attention .

Thereafter the patient underwent split-night polysomnography in August 2013 .

This study revealed severe OSA with an AHI of 75.9 .

At that point he was titrated to 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure .

Subjectively the patient noticed significant improvement with regard to reduction in daytime sleepiness .

Overall he has done rather well as best I can tell with regard to the use of positive pressure over the years .

Unfortunately he's never had any form of structured follow-up from a sleep medicine standpoint .

He remains on his previous 9 cm a fixed CPAP .

He currently utilizes an oronasal mask-likely dreamwear full mask

He wishes to establish care with a sleep medicine physician for reevaluation of adequacy of therapy as well as long-term follow-up .

He's had no issues regarding pressure intolerance .

Currently he is comfortable with his present interface .

In fact he ordered a mini CPAP for travel and has done well in this regard .

He is due for a new CPAP machine as it's been over 5 years with his current device .

He is interested in having the ability to follow his data by smart phone app on a regular basis .

Bedtime 11:30 PM and wake time 5:30 AM .

Probably getting less sleep than he should be getting as he would ideally prefer to sleep from roughly 10

PM until 6 AM . Otherwise functioning well and denies any additional complaints at this point .

Pasco Bond DOB : 24/09/1974 Page 3 of 7

Pasco Bond DOB : 24/09/1974 Page 4 of 7

Progress Notes ( continued )

Assessment and plan

* Severe OSA ( AHI 75.9 ):

The patient has been maintained on 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure for the last 5 years .

He has done well with regard to acceptance adherence and response over those years .

Unfortunately he has not had anyone from a sleep medicine standpoint to provide ongoing observation and care .

He is due for a new CPAP machine and I have ordered one today which will be auto PAP capable but currently at a fixed pressure of 9 cm .

I will evaluate his data moving forward on those pressures .

For the most part he is wearing a comfortable mask but wishes to have additional mask options reviewed with him .

I provided him with the sleep lab telephone number for a mask fit session .

We will make any necessary adjustments with regard to pressure delivery once we have some data from his new device .

Today in the office to review the condition of OSA great length .

We reviewed his sleep study in detail .

We reviewed the main therapeutic options currently available for OSA including air pressure therapy , oral appliance , surgery and hypoglossal nerve stimulator .

We discussed the long-term complications of untreated OSA particularly in its severe form .

I'm pleased with how well he is done over the years .

It is my suspicion that his OSA is primarily secondary to crowded posterior oropharynx noted on examination in conjunction with mild overweight state .

* Overweight ( BMI 28.5 ):

We discussed the effect of weight on OSA as well as weight loss .

* Nasal congestion : He is maintained on Claritin and Flonase along with Sudafed .

We discussed these issues as relates to nasal congestion and the ability to utilize a nasal mask or nasal pillows interface .

I suspect he will continue to be best served with utilization of some formal fullface mask interface .

* RTO in 6-8 weeks for close follow-up .

Orders Placed This Encounter loratadine ( CLARITIN ) 10 mg oral tablet

Sig : Take 10 mg by mouth daily

CPAP ( 1 Marcela Drive DME )

Electronically submitted to DME Supplier

Progress Notes

Progress Notes signed by Pauline Bos , MD at 1/10/2018 1:08 PM Author : Pauline Bos , Author Physician Filed :

MD Type : Note Signed Cosign : Cosign Not Required Encounter 1/10/2018

Status : Date : Editor : CC : OSA

History of present illness

Very pleasant 52-year-old man with a long-standing history of chronic snoring along with prior septoplasty in high school .

He recalls symptoms of chronic sleepiness dating back many years as well which he states limited his ability to be the best Astronomer ever dispiste his success with Led Zeppelin as the lead guitarist . Within the context of these symptoms his wife ( Rosalind Columbia ) noticed witnessed apneas which were brought to his attention .

Thereafter the patient underwent split-night polysomnography in August 2013 .

This study revealed severe OSA with an AHI of 75.9 .

At that point he was titrated to 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure .

Subjectively the patient noticed significant improvement with regard to reduction in daytime sleepiness .

Overall he has done rather well as best I can tell with regard to the use of positive pressure over the years .

Unfortunately he's never had any form of structured follow-up from a sleep medicine standpoint .

He remains on his previous 9 cm a fixed CPAP .

He currently utilizes an oronasal mask-likely dreamwear full mask

He wishes to establish care with a sleep medicine physician for reevaluation of adequacy of therapy as well as long-term follow-up .

He's had no issues regarding pressure intolerance .

Currently he is comfortable with his present interface .

In fact he ordered a mini CPAP for travel and has done well in this regard .

He is due for a new CPAP machine as it's been over 5 years with his current device .

He is interested in having the ability to follow his data by smart phone app on a regular basis .

Bedtime 11:30 PM and wake time 5:30 AM .

Probably getting less sleep than he should be getting as he would ideally prefer to sleep from roughly 10

PM until 6 AM . Otherwise functioning well and denies any additional complaints at this point .

Progress Notes ( continued )

Assessment and plan

* Severe OSA ( AHI 75.9 ):

The patient has been maintained on 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure for the last 5 years .

He has done well with regard to acceptance adherence and response over those years .

Unfortunately he has not had anyone from a sleep medicine standpoint to provide ongoing observation and care .

He is due for a new CPAP machine and I have ordered one today which will be auto PAP capable but currently at a fixed pressure of 9 cm .

I will evaluate his data moving forward on those pressures .

For the most part he is wearing a comfortable mask but wishes to have additional mask options reviewed with him .

I provided him with the sleep lab telephone number for a mask fit session .

We will make any necessary adjustments with regard to pressure delivery once we have some data from his new device .

Today in the office to review the condition of OSA great length .

We reviewed his sleep study in detail .

We reviewed the main therapeutic options currently available for OSA including air pressure therapy , oral appliance , surgery and hypoglossal nerve stimulator .

We discussed the long-term complications of untreated OSA particularly in its severe form .

I'm pleased with how well he is done over the years .

It is my suspicion that his OSA is primarily secondary to crowded posterior oropharynx noted on examination in conjunction with mild overweight state .

* Overweight ( BMI 28.5 ):

We discussed the effect of weight on OSA as well as weight loss .

* Nasal congestion : He is maintained on Claritin and Flonase along with Sudafed .

We discussed these issues as relates to nasal congestion and the ability to utilize a nasal mask or nasal pillows interface .

I suspect he will continue to be best served with utilization of some formal fullface mask interface .

* RTO in 6-8 weeks for close follow-up .

Pasco Bond DOB : 24/09/1974 Page 4 of 7

Progress Notes ( continued )

Assessment and plan

* Severe OSA ( AHI 75.9 ):

The patient has been maintained on 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure for the last 5 years .

He has done well with regard to acceptance adherence and response over those years .

Unfortunately he has not had anyone from a sleep medicine standpoint to provide ongoing observation and care .

He is due for a new CPAP machine and I have ordered one today which will be auto PAP capable but currently at a fixed pressure of 9 cm .

I will evaluate his data moving forward on those pressures .

For the most part he is wearing a comfortable mask but wishes to have additional mask options reviewed with him .

I provided him with the sleep lab telephone number for a mask fit session .

We will make any necessary adjustments with regard to pressure delivery once we have some data from his new device .

Today in the office to review the condition of OSA great length .

We reviewed his sleep study in detail .

We reviewed the main therapeutic options currently available for OSA including air pressure therapy , oral appliance , surgery and hypoglossal nerve stimulator .

We discussed the long-term complications of untreated OSA particularly in its severe form .

I'm pleased with how well he is done over the years .

It is my suspicion that his OSA is primarily secondary to crowded posterior oropharynx noted on examination in conjunction with mild overweight state .

* Overweight ( BMI 28.5 ):

We discussed the effect of weight on OSA as well as weight loss .

* Nasal congestion : He is maintained on Claritin and Flonase along with Sudafed .

We discussed these issues as relates to nasal congestion and the ability to utilize a nasal mask or nasal pillows interface .

I suspect he will continue to be best served with utilization of some formal fullface mask interface .

* RTO in 6-8 weeks for close follow-up .

OSA ( obstructive sleep apnea ) - Primary G47.33

Progress Notes

Progress Notes signed by Pauline Bos , MD at 1/10/2018 1:08 PM Author : Pauline Bos , Author Physician Filed :

MD Type : Note Signed Cosign : Cosign Not Required Encounter 1/10/2018

Status : Date : Editor : CC : OSA

History of present illness

Very pleasant 52-year-old man with a long-standing history of chronic snoring along with prior septoplasty in high school .

He recalls symptoms of chronic sleepiness dating back many years as well which he states limited his ability to be the best Astronomer ever dispiste his success with Led Zeppelin as the lead guitarist . Within the context of these symptoms his wife ( Rosalind Columbia ) noticed witnessed apneas which were brought to his attention .

Thereafter the patient underwent split-night polysomnography in August 2013 .

This study revealed severe OSA with an AHI of 75.9 .

At that point he was titrated to 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure .

Subjectively the patient noticed significant improvement with regard to reduction in daytime sleepiness .

Overall he has done rather well as best I can tell with regard to the use of positive pressure over the years .

Unfortunately he's never had any form of structured follow-up from a sleep medicine standpoint .

He remains on his previous 9 cm a fixed CPAP .

He currently utilizes an oronasal mask-likely dreamwear full mask

He wishes to establish care with a sleep medicine physician for reevaluation of adequacy of therapy as well as long-term follow-up .

He's had no issues regarding pressure intolerance .

Currently he is comfortable with his present interface .

In fact he ordered a mini CPAP for travel and has done well in this regard .

He is due for a new CPAP machine as it's been over 5 years with his current device .

He is interested in having the ability to follow his data by smart phone app on a regular basis .

Bedtime 11:30 PM and wake time 5:30 AM .

Probably getting less sleep than he should be getting as he would ideally prefer to sleep from roughly 10

PM until 6 AM . Otherwise functioning well and denies any additional complaints at this point .

OSA ( obstructive sleep apnea ) - Primary G47.33

Progress Notes

Progress Notes signed by Pauline Bos , MD at 1/10/2018 1:08 PM Author : Pauline Bos , Author Physician Filed :

MD Type : Note Signed Cosign : Cosign Not Required Encounter 1/10/2018

Status : Date : Editor : CC : OSA

History of present illness

Very pleasant 52-year-old man with a long-standing history of chronic snoring along with prior septoplasty in high school .

He recalls symptoms of chronic sleepiness dating back many years as well which he states limited his ability to be the best Astronomer ever dispiste his success with Led Zeppelin as the lead guitarist . Within the context of these symptoms his wife ( Rosalind Columbia ) noticed witnessed apneas which were brought to his attention .

Thereafter the patient underwent split-night polysomnography in August 2013 .

This study revealed severe OSA with an AHI of 75.9 .

At that point he was titrated to 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure .

Subjectively the patient noticed significant improvement with regard to reduction in daytime sleepiness .

Overall he has done rather well as best I can tell with regard to the use of positive pressure over the years .

Unfortunately he's never had any form of structured follow-up from a sleep medicine standpoint .

He remains on his previous 9 cm a fixed CPAP .

He currently utilizes an oronasal mask-likely dreamwear full mask

He wishes to establish care with a sleep medicine physician for reevaluation of adequacy of therapy as well as long-term follow-up .

He's had no issues regarding pressure intolerance .

Currently he is comfortable with his present interface .

In fact he ordered a mini CPAP for travel and has done well in this regard .

He is due for a new CPAP machine as it's been over 5 years with his current device .

He is interested in having the ability to follow his data by smart phone app on a regular basis .

Bedtime 11:30 PM and wake time 5:30 AM .

Probably getting less sleep than he should be getting as he would ideally prefer to sleep from roughly 10

PM until 6 AM . Otherwise functioning well and denies any additional complaints at this point .

Pasco Bond DOB : 24/09/1974 Page 3 of 7

Pasco Bond DOB : 24/09/1974 Page 4 of 7

Progress Notes ( continued )

Assessment and plan

* Severe OSA ( AHI 75.9 ):

The patient has been maintained on 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure for the last 5 years .

He has done well with regard to acceptance adherence and response over those years .

Unfortunately he has not had anyone from a sleep medicine standpoint to provide ongoing observation and care .

He is due for a new CPAP machine and I have ordered one today which will be auto PAP capable but currently at a fixed pressure of 9 cm .

I will evaluate his data moving forward on those pressures .

For the most part he is wearing a comfortable mask but wishes to have additional mask options reviewed with him .

I provided him with the sleep lab telephone number for a mask fit session .

We will make any necessary adjustments with regard to pressure delivery once we have some data from his new device .

Today in the office to review the condition of OSA great length .

We reviewed his sleep study in detail .

We reviewed the main therapeutic options currently available for OSA including air pressure therapy , oral appliance , surgery and hypoglossal nerve stimulator .

We discussed the long-term complications of untreated OSA particularly in its severe form .

I'm pleased with how well he is done over the years .

It is my suspicion that his OSA is primarily secondary to crowded posterior oropharynx noted on examination in conjunction with mild overweight state .

* Overweight ( BMI 28.5 ):

We discussed the effect of weight on OSA as well as weight loss .

* Nasal congestion : He is maintained on Claritin and Flonase along with Sudafed .

We discussed these issues as relates to nasal congestion and the ability to utilize a nasal mask or nasal pillows interface .

I suspect he will continue to be best served with utilization of some formal fullface mask interface .

* RTO in 6-8 weeks for close follow-up .

Orders Placed This Encounter loratadine ( CLARITIN ) 10 mg oral tablet

Sig : Take 10 mg by mouth daily

Progress Notes

Progress Notes signed by Pauline Bos , MD at 1/10/2018 1:08 PM Author : Pauline Bos , Author Physician Filed :

MD Type : Note Signed Cosign : Cosign Not Required Encounter 1/10/2018

Status : Date : Editor : CC : OSA

History of present illness

Very pleasant 52-year-old man with a long-standing history of chronic snoring along with prior septoplasty in high school .

He recalls symptoms of chronic sleepiness dating back many years as well which he states limited his ability to be the best Astronomer ever dispiste his success with Led Zeppelin as the lead guitarist . Within the context of these symptoms his wife ( Rosalind Columbia ) noticed witnessed apneas which were brought to his attention .

Thereafter the patient underwent split-night polysomnography in August 2013 .

This study revealed severe OSA with an AHI of 75.9 .

At that point he was titrated to 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure .

Subjectively the patient noticed significant improvement with regard to reduction in daytime sleepiness .

Overall he has done rather well as best I can tell with regard to the use of positive pressure over the years .

Unfortunately he's never had any form of structured follow-up from a sleep medicine standpoint .

He remains on his previous 9 cm a fixed CPAP .

He currently utilizes an oronasal mask-likely dreamwear full mask

He wishes to establish care with a sleep medicine physician for reevaluation of adequacy of therapy as well as long-term follow-up .

He's had no issues regarding pressure intolerance .

Currently he is comfortable with his present interface .

In fact he ordered a mini CPAP for travel and has done well in this regard .

He is due for a new CPAP machine as it's been over 5 years with his current device .

He is interested in having the ability to follow his data by smart phone app on a regular basis .

Bedtime 11:30 PM and wake time 5:30 AM .

Probably getting less sleep than he should be getting as he would ideally prefer to sleep from roughly 10

PM until 6 AM . Otherwise functioning well and denies any additional complaints at this point .

Progress Notes ( continued )

Assessment and plan

* Severe OSA ( AHI 75.9 ):

The patient has been maintained on 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure for the last 5 years .

He has done well with regard to acceptance adherence and response over those years .

Unfortunately he has not had anyone from a sleep medicine standpoint to provide ongoing observation and care .

He is due for a new CPAP machine and I have ordered one today which will be auto PAP capable but currently at a fixed pressure of 9 cm .

I will evaluate his data moving forward on those pressures .

For the most part he is wearing a comfortable mask but wishes to have additional mask options reviewed with him .

I provided him with the sleep lab telephone number for a mask fit session .

We will make any necessary adjustments with regard to pressure delivery once we have some data from his new device .

Today in the office to review the condition of OSA great length .

We reviewed his sleep study in detail .

We reviewed the main therapeutic options currently available for OSA including air pressure therapy , oral appliance , surgery and hypoglossal nerve stimulator .

We discussed the long-term complications of untreated OSA particularly in its severe form .

I'm pleased with how well he is done over the years .

It is my suspicion that his OSA is primarily secondary to crowded posterior oropharynx noted on examination in conjunction with mild overweight state .

* Overweight ( BMI 28.5 ):

We discussed the effect of weight on OSA as well as weight loss .

* Nasal congestion : He is maintained on Claritin and Flonase along with Sudafed .

We discussed these issues as relates to nasal congestion and the ability to utilize a nasal mask or nasal pillows interface .

I suspect he will continue to be best served with utilization of some formal fullface mask interface .

* RTO in 6-8 weeks for close follow-up .

Progress Notes ( continued )

Assessment and plan

* Severe OSA ( AHI 75.9 ):

The patient has been maintained on 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure for the last 5 years .

He has done well with regard to acceptance adherence and response over those years .

Unfortunately he has not had anyone from a sleep medicine standpoint to provide ongoing observation and care .

He is due for a new CPAP machine and I have ordered one today which will be auto PAP capable but currently at a fixed pressure of 9 cm .

I will evaluate his data moving forward on those pressures .

For the most part he is wearing a comfortable mask but wishes to have additional mask options reviewed with him .

I provided him with the sleep lab telephone number for a mask fit session .

We will make any necessary adjustments with regard to pressure delivery once we have some data from his new device .

Today in the office to review the condition of OSA great length .

We reviewed his sleep study in detail .

We reviewed the main therapeutic options currently available for OSA including air pressure therapy , oral appliance , surgery and hypoglossal nerve stimulator .

We discussed the long-term complications of untreated OSA particularly in its severe form .

I'm pleased with how well he is done over the years .

It is my suspicion that his OSA is primarily secondary to crowded posterior oropharynx noted on examination in conjunction with mild overweight state .

* Overweight ( BMI 28.5 ):

We discussed the effect of weight on OSA as well as weight loss .

* Nasal congestion : He is maintained on Claritin and Flonase along with Sudafed .

We discussed these issues as relates to nasal congestion and the ability to utilize a nasal mask or nasal pillows interface .

I suspect he will continue to be best served with utilization of some formal fullface mask interface .

* RTO in 6-8 weeks for close follow-up .

Progress Notes

Progress Notes signed by Pauline Bos , MD at 1/10/2018 1:08 PM Author : Pauline Bos , Author Physician Filed :

MD Type : Note Signed Cosign : Cosign Not Required Encounter 1/10/2018

Status : Date : Editor : CC : OSA

History of present illness

Very pleasant 52-year-old man with a long-standing history of chronic snoring along with prior septoplasty in high school .

He recalls symptoms of chronic sleepiness dating back many years as well which he states limited his ability to be the best Astronomer ever dispiste his success with Led Zeppelin as the lead guitarist . Within the context of these symptoms his wife ( Rosalind Columbia ) noticed witnessed apneas which were brought to his attention .

Thereafter the patient underwent split-night polysomnography in August 2013 .

This study revealed severe OSA with an AHI of 75.9 .

At that point he was titrated to 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure .

Subjectively the patient noticed significant improvement with regard to reduction in daytime sleepiness .

Overall he has done rather well as best I can tell with regard to the use of positive pressure over the years .

Unfortunately he's never had any form of structured follow-up from a sleep medicine standpoint .

He remains on his previous 9 cm a fixed CPAP .

He currently utilizes an oronasal mask-likely dreamwear full mask

He wishes to establish care with a sleep medicine physician for reevaluation of adequacy of therapy as well as long-term follow-up .

He's had no issues regarding pressure intolerance .

Currently he is comfortable with his present interface .

In fact he ordered a mini CPAP for travel and has done well in this regard .

He is due for a new CPAP machine as it's been over 5 years with his current device .

He is interested in having the ability to follow his data by smart phone app on a regular basis .

Bedtime 11:30 PM and wake time 5:30 AM .

Probably getting less sleep than he should be getting as he would ideally prefer to sleep from roughly 10

PM until 6 AM . Otherwise functioning well and denies any additional complaints at this point .

OSA ( obstructive sleep apnea ) - Primary G47.33

Progress Notes

Progress Notes signed by Pauline Bos , MD at 1/10/2018 1:08 PM Author : Pauline Bos , Author Physician Filed :

MD Type : Note Signed Cosign : Cosign Not Required Encounter 1/10/2018

Status : Date : Editor : CC : OSA

History of present illness

Very pleasant 52-year-old man with a long-standing history of chronic snoring along with prior septoplasty in high school .

He recalls symptoms of chronic sleepiness dating back many years as well which he states limited his ability to be the best Astronomer ever dispiste his success with Led Zeppelin as the lead guitarist . Within the context of these symptoms his wife ( Rosalind Columbia ) noticed witnessed apneas which were brought to his attention .

Thereafter the patient underwent split-night polysomnography in August 2013 .

This study revealed severe OSA with an AHI of 75.9 .

At that point he was titrated to 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure .

Subjectively the patient noticed significant improvement with regard to reduction in daytime sleepiness .

Overall he has done rather well as best I can tell with regard to the use of positive pressure over the years .

Unfortunately he's never had any form of structured follow-up from a sleep medicine standpoint .

He remains on his previous 9 cm a fixed CPAP .

He currently utilizes an oronasal mask-likely dreamwear full mask

He wishes to establish care with a sleep medicine physician for reevaluation of adequacy of therapy as well as long-term follow-up .

He's had no issues regarding pressure intolerance .

Currently he is comfortable with his present interface .

In fact he ordered a mini CPAP for travel and has done well in this regard .

He is due for a new CPAP machine as it's been over 5 years with his current device .

He is interested in having the ability to follow his data by smart phone app on a regular basis .

Bedtime 11:30 PM and wake time 5:30 AM .

Probably getting less sleep than he should be getting as he would ideally prefer to sleep from roughly 10

PM until 6 AM . Otherwise functioning well and denies any additional complaints at this point .

Pasco Bond DOB : 24/09/1974 Page 4 of 7

Progress Notes ( continued )

Assessment and plan

* Severe OSA ( AHI 75.9 ):

The patient has been maintained on 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure for the last 5 years .

He has done well with regard to acceptance adherence and response over those years .

Unfortunately he has not had anyone from a sleep medicine standpoint to provide ongoing observation and care .

He is due for a new CPAP machine and I have ordered one today which will be auto PAP capable but currently at a fixed pressure of 9 cm .

I will evaluate his data moving forward on those pressures .

For the most part he is wearing a comfortable mask but wishes to have additional mask options reviewed with him .

I provided him with the sleep lab telephone number for a mask fit session .

We will make any necessary adjustments with regard to pressure delivery once we have some data from his new device .

Today in the office to review the condition of OSA great length .

We reviewed his sleep study in detail .

We reviewed the main therapeutic options currently available for OSA including air pressure therapy , oral appliance , surgery and hypoglossal nerve stimulator .

We discussed the long-term complications of untreated OSA particularly in its severe form .

I'm pleased with how well he is done over the years .

It is my suspicion that his OSA is primarily secondary to crowded posterior oropharynx noted on examination in conjunction with mild overweight state .

* Overweight ( BMI 28.5 ):

We discussed the effect of weight on OSA as well as weight loss .

* Nasal congestion : He is maintained on Claritin and Flonase along with Sudafed .

We discussed these issues as relates to nasal congestion and the ability to utilize a nasal mask or nasal pillows interface .

I suspect he will continue to be best served with utilization of some formal fullface mask interface .

* RTO in 6-8 weeks for close follow-up .

I provided him with the sleep lab telephone number for a mask fit session .

We will make any necessary adjustments with regard to pressure delivery once we have some data from his new device .

Today in the office to review the condition of OSA great length .

We reviewed his sleep study in detail .

We reviewed the main therapeutic options currently available for OSA including air pressure therapy , oral appliance , surgery and hypoglossal nerve stimulator .

We discussed the long-term complications of untreated OSA particularly in its severe form .

I'm pleased with how well he is done over the years .

It is my suspicion that his OSA is primarily secondary to crowded posterior oropharynx noted on examination in conjunction with mild overweight state .

* Overweight ( BMI 28.5 ):

We discussed the effect of weight on OSA as well as weight loss .

* Nasal congestion : He is maintained on Claritin and Flonase along with Sudafed .

We discussed these issues as relates to nasal congestion and the ability to utilize a nasal mask or nasal pillows interface .

I suspect he will continue to be best served with utilization of some formal fullface mask interface .

* RTO in 6-8 weeks for close follow-up .

Progress Notes

Progress Notes signed by Pauline Bos , MD at 1/10/2018 1:08 PM Author : Pauline Bos , Author Physician Filed :

MD Type : Note Signed Cosign : Cosign Not Required Encounter 1/10/2018

Status : Date : Editor : CC : OSA

History of present illness

Very pleasant 52-year-old man with a long-standing history of chronic snoring along with prior septoplasty in high school .

He recalls symptoms of chronic sleepiness dating back many years as well which he states limited his ability to be the best Astronomer ever dispiste his success with Led Zeppelin as the lead guitarist . Within the context of these symptoms his wife ( Rosalind Columbia ) noticed witnessed apneas which were brought to his attention .

Thereafter the patient underwent split-night polysomnography in August 2013 .

This study revealed severe OSA with an AHI of 75.9 .

At that point he was titrated to 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure .

Subjectively the patient noticed significant improvement with regard to reduction in daytime sleepiness .

Overall he has done rather well as best I can tell with regard to the use of positive pressure over the years .

Unfortunately he's never had any form of structured follow-up from a sleep medicine standpoint .

He remains on his previous 9 cm a fixed CPAP .

He currently utilizes an oronasal mask-likely dreamwear full mask

He wishes to establish care with a sleep medicine physician for reevaluation of adequacy of therapy as well as long-term follow-up .

He's had no issues regarding pressure intolerance .

Currently he is comfortable with his present interface .

In fact he ordered a mini CPAP for travel and has done well in this regard .

He is due for a new CPAP machine as it's been over 5 years with his current device .

He is interested in having the ability to follow his data by smart phone app on a regular basis .

Bedtime 11:30 PM and wake time 5:30 AM .

Probably getting less sleep than he should be getting as he would ideally prefer to sleep from roughly 10

PM until 6 AM . Otherwise functioning well and denies any additional complaints at this point .

In fact he ordered a mini CPAP for travel and has done well in this regard .

He is due for a new CPAP machine as it's been over 5 years with his current device .

He is interested in having the ability to follow his data by smart phone app on a regular basis .

Bedtime 11:30 PM and wake time 5:30 AM .

Probably getting less sleep than he should be getting as he would ideally prefer to sleep from roughly 10

PM until 6 AM . Otherwise functioning well and denies any additional complaints at this point .

Progress Notes ( continued )

Assessment and plan

* Severe OSA ( AHI 75.9 ):

The patient has been maintained on 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure for the last 5 years .

He has done well with regard to acceptance adherence and response over those years .

Unfortunately he has not had anyone from a sleep medicine standpoint to provide ongoing observation and care .

He is due for a new CPAP machine and I have ordered one today which will be auto PAP capable but currently at a fixed pressure of 9 cm .

I will evaluate his data moving forward on those pressures .

For the most part he is wearing a comfortable mask but wishes to have additional mask options reviewed with him .

I provided him with the sleep lab telephone number for a mask fit session .

We will make any necessary adjustments with regard to pressure delivery once we have some data from his new device .

Today in the office to review the condition of OSA great length .

We reviewed his sleep study in detail .

We reviewed the main therapeutic options currently available for OSA including air pressure therapy , oral appliance , surgery and hypoglossal nerve stimulator .

We discussed the long-term complications of untreated OSA particularly in its severe form .

I'm pleased with how well he is done over the years .

It is my suspicion that his OSA is primarily secondary to crowded posterior oropharynx noted on examination in conjunction with mild overweight state .

* Overweight ( BMI 28.5 ):

We discussed the effect of weight on OSA as well as weight loss .

* Nasal congestion : He is maintained on Claritin and Flonase along with Sudafed .

We discussed these issues as relates to nasal congestion and the ability to utilize a nasal mask or nasal pillows interface .

I suspect he will continue to be best served with utilization of some formal fullface mask interface .

* RTO in 6-8 weeks for close follow-up .

Progress Notes

Progress Notes signed by Pauline Bos , MD at 1/10/2018 1:08 PM Author : Pauline Bos , Author Physician Filed :

MD Type : Note Signed Cosign : Cosign Not Required Encounter 1/10/2018

Status : Date : Editor : CC : OSA

History of present illness

Very pleasant 52-year-old man with a long-standing history of chronic snoring along with prior septoplasty in high school .

He recalls symptoms of chronic sleepiness dating back many years as well which he states limited his ability to be the best Astronomer ever dispiste his success with Led Zeppelin as the lead guitarist . Within the context of these symptoms his wife ( Rosalind Columbia ) noticed witnessed apneas which were brought to his attention .

Thereafter the patient underwent split-night polysomnography in August 2013 .

This study revealed severe OSA with an AHI of 75.9 .

At that point he was titrated to 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure .

Subjectively the patient noticed significant improvement with regard to reduction in daytime sleepiness .

Overall he has done rather well as best I can tell with regard to the use of positive pressure over the years .

Unfortunately he's never had any form of structured follow-up from a sleep medicine standpoint .

He remains on his previous 9 cm a fixed CPAP .

He currently utilizes an oronasal mask-likely dreamwear full mask

He wishes to establish care with a sleep medicine physician for reevaluation of adequacy of therapy as well as long-term follow-up .

He's had no issues regarding pressure intolerance .

Currently he is comfortable with his present interface .

In fact he ordered a mini CPAP for travel and has done well in this regard .

He is due for a new CPAP machine as it's been over 5 years with his current device .

He is interested in having the ability to follow his data by smart phone app on a regular basis .

Bedtime 11:30 PM and wake time 5:30 AM .

Probably getting less sleep than he should be getting as he would ideally prefer to sleep from roughly 10

PM until 6 AM . Otherwise functioning well and denies any additional complaints at this point .

OSA ( obstructive sleep apnea ) - Primary G47.33

Progress Notes

Progress Notes signed by Pauline Bos , MD at 1/10/2018 1:08 PM Author : Pauline Bos , Author Physician Filed :

MD Type : Note Signed Cosign : Cosign Not Required Encounter 1/10/2018

Status : Date : Editor : CC : OSA

History of present illness

Very pleasant 52-year-old man with a long-standing history of chronic snoring along with prior septoplasty in high school .

He recalls symptoms of chronic sleepiness dating back many years as well which he states limited his ability to be the best Astronomer ever dispiste his success with Led Zeppelin as the lead guitarist . Within the context of these symptoms his wife ( Rosalind Columbia ) noticed witnessed apneas which were brought to his attention .

Thereafter the patient underwent split-night polysomnography in August 2013 .

This study revealed severe OSA with an AHI of 75.9 .

At that point he was titrated to 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure .

Subjectively the patient noticed significant improvement with regard to reduction in daytime sleepiness .

Overall he has done rather well as best I can tell with regard to the use of positive pressure over the years .

Unfortunately he's never had any form of structured follow-up from a sleep medicine standpoint .

He remains on his previous 9 cm a fixed CPAP .

He currently utilizes an oronasal mask-likely dreamwear full mask

He wishes to establish care with a sleep medicine physician for reevaluation of adequacy of therapy as well as long-term follow-up .

He's had no issues regarding pressure intolerance .

Currently he is comfortable with his present interface .

In fact he ordered a mini CPAP for travel and has done well in this regard .

He is due for a new CPAP machine as it's been over 5 years with his current device .

He is interested in having the ability to follow his data by smart phone app on a regular basis .

Bedtime 11:30 PM and wake time 5:30 AM .

Probably getting less sleep than he should be getting as he would ideally prefer to sleep from roughly 10

PM until 6 AM . Otherwise functioning well and denies any additional complaints at this point .

Pasco Bond DOB : 24/09/1974 Page 3 of 7

Pasco Bond DOB : 24/09/1974 Page 4 of 7

Progress Notes ( continued )

Assessment and plan

* Severe OSA ( AHI 75.9 ):

The patient has been maintained on 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure for the last 5 years .

He has done well with regard to acceptance adherence and response over those years .

Unfortunately he has not had anyone from a sleep medicine standpoint to provide ongoing observation and care .

He is due for a new CPAP machine and I have ordered one today which will be auto PAP capable but currently at a fixed pressure of 9 cm .

I will evaluate his data moving forward on those pressures .

For the most part he is wearing a comfortable mask but wishes to have additional mask options reviewed with him .

I provided him with the sleep lab telephone number for a mask fit session .

We will make any necessary adjustments with regard to pressure delivery once we have some data from his new device .

Today in the office to review the condition of OSA great length .

We reviewed his sleep study in detail .

We reviewed the main therapeutic options currently available for OSA including air pressure therapy , oral appliance , surgery and hypoglossal nerve stimulator .

We discussed the long-term complications of untreated OSA particularly in its severe form .

I'm pleased with how well he is done over the years .

It is my suspicion that his OSA is primarily secondary to crowded posterior oropharynx noted on examination in conjunction with mild overweight state .

* Overweight ( BMI 28.5 ):

We discussed the effect of weight on OSA as well as weight loss .

* Nasal congestion : He is maintained on Claritin and Flonase along with Sudafed .

We discussed these issues as relates to nasal congestion and the ability to utilize a nasal mask or nasal pillows interface .

I suspect he will continue to be best served with utilization of some formal fullface mask interface .

* RTO in 6-8 weeks for close follow-up .

Pasco Bond DOB : 24/09/1974 Page 4 of 7

Progress Notes ( continued )

Assessment and plan

* Severe OSA ( AHI 75.9 ):

The patient has been maintained on 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure for the last 5 years .

He has done well with regard to acceptance adherence and response over those years .

Unfortunately he has not had anyone from a sleep medicine standpoint to provide ongoing observation and care .

He is due for a new CPAP machine and I have ordered one today which will be auto PAP capable but currently at a fixed pressure of 9 cm .

I will evaluate his data moving forward on those pressures .

For the most part he is wearing a comfortable mask but wishes to have additional mask options reviewed with him .

I provided him with the sleep lab telephone number for a mask fit session .

We will make any necessary adjustments with regard to pressure delivery once we have some data from his new device .

Today in the office to review the condition of OSA great length .

We reviewed his sleep study in detail .

We reviewed the main therapeutic options currently available for OSA including air pressure therapy , oral appliance , surgery and hypoglossal nerve stimulator .

We discussed the long-term complications of untreated OSA particularly in its severe form .

I'm pleased with how well he is done over the years .

It is my suspicion that his OSA is primarily secondary to crowded posterior oropharynx noted on examination in conjunction with mild overweight state .

* Overweight ( BMI 28.5 ):

We discussed the effect of weight on OSA as well as weight loss .

* Nasal congestion : He is maintained on Claritin and Flonase along with Sudafed .

We discussed these issues as relates to nasal congestion and the ability to utilize a nasal mask or nasal pillows interface .

I suspect he will continue to be best served with utilization of some formal fullface mask interface .

* RTO in 6-8 weeks for close follow-up .

Progress Notes

Progress Notes signed by Pauline Bos , MD at 1/10/2018 1:08 PM Author : Pauline Bos , Author Physician Filed :

MD Type : Note Signed Cosign : Cosign Not Required Encounter 1/10/2018

Status : Date : Editor : CC : OSA

History of present illness

Very pleasant 52-year-old man with a long-standing history of chronic snoring along with prior septoplasty in high school .

He recalls symptoms of chronic sleepiness dating back many years as well which he states limited his ability to be the best Astronomer ever dispiste his success with Led Zeppelin as the lead guitarist . Within the context of these symptoms his wife ( Rosalind Columbia ) noticed witnessed apneas which were brought to his attention .

Thereafter the patient underwent split-night polysomnography in August 2013 .

This study revealed severe OSA with an AHI of 75.9 .

At that point he was titrated to 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure .

Subjectively the patient noticed significant improvement with regard to reduction in daytime sleepiness .

Overall he has done rather well as best I can tell with regard to the use of positive pressure over the years .

Unfortunately he's never had any form of structured follow-up from a sleep medicine standpoint .

He remains on his previous 9 cm a fixed CPAP .

He currently utilizes an oronasal mask-likely dreamwear full mask

He wishes to establish care with a sleep medicine physician for reevaluation of adequacy of therapy as well as long-term follow-up .

He's had no issues regarding pressure intolerance .

Currently he is comfortable with his present interface .

In fact he ordered a mini CPAP for travel and has done well in this regard .

He is due for a new CPAP machine as it's been over 5 years with his current device .

He is interested in having the ability to follow his data by smart phone app on a regular basis .

Bedtime 11:30 PM and wake time 5:30 AM .

Probably getting less sleep than he should be getting as he would ideally prefer to sleep from roughly 10

PM until 6 AM . Otherwise functioning well and denies any additional complaints at this point .

Within the context of these symptoms his wife ( Rosalind Columbia ) noticed witnessed apneas which were brought to his attention .

Thereafter the patient underwent split-night polysomnography in August 2013 .

This study revealed severe OSA with an AHI of 75.9 .

At that point he was titrated to 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure .

Subjectively the patient noticed significant improvement with regard to reduction in daytime sleepiness .

Overall he has done rather well as best I can tell with regard to the use of positive pressure over the years .

Unfortunately he's never had any form of structured follow-up from a sleep medicine standpoint .

He remains on his previous 9 cm a fixed CPAP .

He currently utilizes an oronasal mask-likely dreamwear full mask

He wishes to establish care with a sleep medicine physician for reevaluation of adequacy of therapy as well as long-term follow-up .

He's had no issues regarding pressure intolerance .

Currently he is comfortable with his present interface .

In fact he ordered a mini CPAP for travel and has done well in this regard .

He is due for a new CPAP machine as it's been over 5 years with his current device .

He is interested in having the ability to follow his data by smart phone app on a regular basis .

Bedtime 11:30 PM and wake time 5:30 AM .

Probably getting less sleep than he should be getting as he would ideally prefer to sleep from roughly 10

PM until 6 AM . Otherwise functioning well and denies any additional complaints at this point .

Progress Notes ( continued )

Assessment and plan

* Severe OSA ( AHI 75.9 ):

The patient has been maintained on 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure for the last 5 years .

He has done well with regard to acceptance adherence and response over those years .

Unfortunately he has not had anyone from a sleep medicine standpoint to provide ongoing observation and care .

He is due for a new CPAP machine and I have ordered one today which will be auto PAP capable but currently at a fixed pressure of 9 cm .

I will evaluate his data moving forward on those pressures .

For the most part he is wearing a comfortable mask but wishes to have additional mask options reviewed with him .

I provided him with the sleep lab telephone number for a mask fit session .

We will make any necessary adjustments with regard to pressure delivery once we have some data from his new device .

Today in the office to review the condition of OSA great length .

We reviewed his sleep study in detail .

We reviewed the main therapeutic options currently available for OSA including air pressure therapy , oral appliance , surgery and hypoglossal nerve stimulator .

We discussed the long-term complications of untreated OSA particularly in its severe form .

I'm pleased with how well he is done over the years .

It is my suspicion that his OSA is primarily secondary to crowded posterior oropharynx noted on examination in conjunction with mild overweight state .

* Overweight ( BMI 28.5 ):

We discussed the effect of weight on OSA as well as weight loss .

* Nasal congestion : He is maintained on Claritin and Flonase along with Sudafed .

We discussed these issues as relates to nasal congestion and the ability to utilize a nasal mask or nasal pillows interface .

I suspect he will continue to be best served with utilization of some formal fullface mask interface .

* RTO in 6-8 weeks for close follow-up .

Orders Placed This Encounter loratadine ( CLARITIN ) 10 mg oral tablet

OSA ( obstructive sleep apnea ) - Primary G47.33

Progress Notes

Progress Notes signed by Pauline Bos , MD at 1/10/2018 1:08 PM Author : Pauline Bos , Author Physician Filed :

MD Type : Note Signed Cosign : Cosign Not Required Encounter 1/10/2018

Status : Date : Editor : CC : OSA

History of present illness

Very pleasant 52-year-old man with a long-standing history of chronic snoring along with prior septoplasty in high school .

He recalls symptoms of chronic sleepiness dating back many years as well which he states limited his ability to be the best Astronomer ever dispiste his success with Led Zeppelin as the lead guitarist . Within the context of these symptoms his wife ( Rosalind Columbia ) noticed witnessed apneas which were brought to his attention .

Thereafter the patient underwent split-night polysomnography in August 2013 .

This study revealed severe OSA with an AHI of 75.9 .

At that point he was titrated to 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure .

Subjectively the patient noticed significant improvement with regard to reduction in daytime sleepiness .

Overall he has done rather well as best I can tell with regard to the use of positive pressure over the years .

Unfortunately he's never had any form of structured follow-up from a sleep medicine standpoint .

He remains on his previous 9 cm a fixed CPAP .

He currently utilizes an oronasal mask-likely dreamwear full mask

He wishes to establish care with a sleep medicine physician for reevaluation of adequacy of therapy as well as long-term follow-up .

He's had no issues regarding pressure intolerance .

Currently he is comfortable with his present interface .

In fact he ordered a mini CPAP for travel and has done well in this regard .

He is due for a new CPAP machine as it's been over 5 years with his current device .

He is interested in having the ability to follow his data by smart phone app on a regular basis .

Bedtime 11:30 PM and wake time 5:30 AM .

Probably getting less sleep than he should be getting as he would ideally prefer to sleep from roughly 10

PM until 6 AM . Otherwise functioning well and denies any additional complaints at this point .

Pasco Bond DOB : 24/09/1974 Page 4 of 7

Progress Notes ( continued )

Assessment and plan

* Severe OSA ( AHI 75.9 ):

The patient has been maintained on 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure for the last 5 years .

He has done well with regard to acceptance adherence and response over those years .

Unfortunately he has not had anyone from a sleep medicine standpoint to provide ongoing observation and care .

He is due for a new CPAP machine and I have ordered one today which will be auto PAP capable but currently at a fixed pressure of 9 cm .

I will evaluate his data moving forward on those pressures .

For the most part he is wearing a comfortable mask but wishes to have additional mask options reviewed with him .

I provided him with the sleep lab telephone number for a mask fit session .

We will make any necessary adjustments with regard to pressure delivery once we have some data from his new device .

Today in the office to review the condition of OSA great length .

We reviewed his sleep study in detail .

We reviewed the main therapeutic options currently available for OSA including air pressure therapy , oral appliance , surgery and hypoglossal nerve stimulator .

We discussed the long-term complications of untreated OSA particularly in its severe form .

I'm pleased with how well he is done over the years .

It is my suspicion that his OSA is primarily secondary to crowded posterior oropharynx noted on examination in conjunction with mild overweight state .

* Overweight ( BMI 28.5 ):

We discussed the effect of weight on OSA as well as weight loss .

* Nasal congestion : He is maintained on Claritin and Flonase along with Sudafed .

We discussed these issues as relates to nasal congestion and the ability to utilize a nasal mask or nasal pillows interface .

I suspect he will continue to be best served with utilization of some formal fullface mask interface .

* RTO in 6-8 weeks for close follow-up .

Pasco Bond DOB : 24/09/1974 Page 4 of 7

Progress Notes ( continued )

Assessment and plan

* Severe OSA ( AHI 75.9 ):

The patient has been maintained on 9 cm fixed CPAP pressure for the last 5 years .

He has done well with regard to acceptance adherence and response over those years .

Unfortunately he has not had anyone from a sleep medicine standpoint to provide ongoing observation and care .

He is due for a new CPAP machine and I have ordered one today which will be auto PAP capable but currently at a fixed pressure of 9 cm .

I will evaluate his data moving forward on those pressures .

For the most part he is wearing a comfortable mask but wishes to have additional mask options reviewed with him .

I provided him with the sleep lab telephone number for a mask fit session .

We will make any necessary adjustments with regard to pressure delivery once we have some data from his new device .

Today in the office to review the condition of OSA great length .

We reviewed his sleep study in detail .

We reviewed the main therapeutic options currently available for OSA including air pressure therapy , oral appliance , surgery and hypoglossal nerve stimulator .

We discussed the long-term complications of untreated OSA particularly in its severe form .

I'm pleased with how well he is done over the years .

It is my suspicion that his OSA is primarily secondary to crowded posterior oropharynx noted on examination in conjunction with mild overweight state .

* Overweight ( BMI 28.5 ):

We discussed the effect of weight on OSA as well as weight loss .

* Nasal congestion : He is maintained on Claritin and Flonase along with Sudafed .

We discussed these issues as relates to nasal congestion and the ability to utilize a nasal mask or nasal pillows interface .

I suspect he will continue to be best served with utilization of some formal fullface mask interface .

* RTO in 6-8 weeks for close follow-up .
